Topic.Title: Remember yesterday's premarket?

Message.Msg: "Normal" in the markets is a relative thing. It is always changing, always responding to many different influences. The choice we have as investors is to pay attention and learn or stand back and get smothered. You are correct in that the Fed stimulus needs to be reigned in, slowly. You are also correct that a lot of folks will panic because they've become dependent on the Fed stimulus. That's a part of what happens when the Fed changes direction. Look at history and you will find similar swings whenever the Feds tightened policy. The key point being that you know it's going to happen so what are you going to do about it? Many will see it as a disaster and panic, while many others will see it as a grand opportunity as they also know that any downturn will not be permanent, that the market will, as it always has, go back up. It's when most people are panicking that the real money can be made for those who can keep their heads on straight.

Message.Title: From The Mind of a Former BAC Short
Message.Msg: Okay, longs....I just wanted to reaffirm my strong buy for BAC first and foremost and begin to explain why I think BAC shares will soon rise...First, as a former short, I can tell you that shorts will be scared to death come Friday afternoon. Once the settlement hearing is over, BAC shorts will have to begin buying back shares. As a former short, I promise you that because they have no idea as to when the settlement news will hit the wires, they would want to be nuetral...What does this means? It means that BAC shares should continue to rise right up until the settlement news at least. Since I suspect the settlement news to be positive, I expect to see BAC go on a tear to the $20 level at least. Once again, BAC bears will have to cover come Friday afternoon. Good luck to all BAC longs!

Message.Title: Record Increae in US Oil Production
Message.Msg: According to the WSJ, US oil production increased by a record 1 million barrels per day this past year. This is what people tend to forget as they look at the US economy. Energy is booming. The US is expected to become energy independent within 5 years. The economy is changing folks. If you are judging what's happening today by what was happening before the financial crisis hit, you are setting yourself up for major failure.

Topic.Title: Record Increae in US Oil Production

Message.Msg: Why? Unless there's something specific about BP's future that makes you nervous, I wouldn't sell simply because the US is becoming energy independent. The flip side of that coin is that China and other countries continue to increase their imports, so the oil the US will no long have to import will find ready buyers elsewhere. All of this could keep a lid on oil prices for awhile, but oil in the rest of the world isn't going to collapse. The markets are simply changing. It's a win for the US as we'll be able to keep more of our dollars here and be able to attract more business here. It's a win for the rest of the world because it takes away the pressure on higher prices, at least for the short term. I tend to think that the US will benefit the most from these changes, but we'll have to see how it plays out.

Message.Title: Bank of America $8.5 Billion Settlement
Message.Msg: Bank of America agreed to the proposed settlement in June 2011 to resolve claims by investors who held bonds issued by mortgage lender Countrywide Financial Corp, which Bank of America bought in 2008. Twenty-two institutional investors, including BlackRock Inc, MetLife Inc and Allianz SE's Pacific Investment Management Co entered into the deal. But American International Group Inc and others objected, saying the settlement offered them only a fraction of the money they lost. Justice Barbara Kapnick of New York State Supreme Court, who will decide the case without a jury, has set aside the first two weeks of June to hear the case. If she rejects the settlement, the parties could face years of litigation. Kathy Patrick, who will argue for the institutional investors who negotiated the deal, said objectors comprise only seven percent of certificate-holders. "There is massive support for this settlement," Patrick said in arguments during a last-minute appeal last week. The proposed deal "offers pennies on the dollar," Colorado attorney Daniel Reilly, who represents AIG, said during last week's arguments. Over 20 AIG entities and the home loan banks of Boston, Indianapolis and Chicago are among 65 opponents of the settlement, he said. The opponents say losses to the trusts might exceed $100 billion, according to court papers. They claim BNY Mellon placed its interests and those of Bank of America above certificate- holders. They point out BNY Mellon gets trust business from the bank. The case was filed by Bank of New York Mellon, the trustee for some 530 trusts that held the securities, asking the court to approve the settlement and declare it binding on all beneficiaries. Matthew Ingber, who represents BNY Mellon, is expected to argue the trustee has the right to settle claims and exercised good faith judgment in deciding the settlement was reasonable. "We believe this $8.5 billion settlement is in the best interests of all the certificate-holders," Ingber sa

Topic.Title: ROFLMFO, inflation at historic lows due to financial services and insurance.

Message.Msg: ROTFLMAO as if your conference's guests deserve any respect. I mean, would I get any if I agreed to present a paper? Or have any left, for that matter? And if so, why? It would take me all of 15 minutes to mulch my staggerwing repair experiences into an economic screed about the costs and perils of inelastic supply AND demand in niche industries, and the mouth-breathing Farmville devotees at your Bundy-Dube conference would lap it up like pigs at a Tyson plant luncheon. It might surprise you to learn that being the only guy on the planet in need of extended longerons for an early Beech-17 [17, say, did I tell you my dog just made it to 17?) does not put you in a particularly strong negotiating position with the only guy on the planet who has a set and yet refuses to discuss anything except in person, and then only in his hangar with noisy equipment running so he has home court advantage, plausible deniability and easy access to lethal power tools (in the staggerwing repair business, 'manny moe and jack' turn out to be one ancient knuckledragger named alonzo, no last name, cash in unmarked bills and don't ask for a receipt). Things like human life expectancy and recent accident rates for pre-1936 Model 17s and whether you prefer domestic or imported whiskey have begun to cloud our discussions, and the excuses for his Ali Baba prices have shifted from daughter's college costs to 3rd wife's alimony payments to current foreclosure proceedings. Oh, what the hell, you know my usual terms. Just don't use the same compounding outfit you engaged for the hospitality suite at last year's conference....talk about bad trips.....

Message.Msg: How has fly fishing been effected by more creative measures of inflation? I haven't bothered to check but I thought they just made a few changes or were talking about it. This has all the signs of a death spiral, can you say something about stall angle when flying a cloth covered plane into a windshear?

Topic.Title: ROFLMFO, inflation at historic lows due to financial services and insurance.

Message.Msg: Who gives a fly-flshing farque how inflation affects feather-flinging fisherfolk? They should be throwing things with less drag that don't stall so easily. Besides, stall angle is irrelevant whenever windshear is encountered; altitude and sink rate are the only things that matter. Can't say I'd be concern about angle of attack or whether the wing was still flying, or whether it was covered with duralumin or fabric, or in a flat spin or a death spiral. My only concern would be the rate at which the ground is rushing up to meet me. I should spum this post into an economic parable and deliver to the Bundy-Dube crowd. ROTFLMAO you must have seen newsreel footage of airmail bag drops from biplanes, yes?

Topic.Title: From The Mind of a Former BAC Short

Message.Msg: How did you like today's action, 5? I kept on buying under 13.....I am where I need to be with BAC shares almost and will wait for things to manifest.

Topic.Title: From The Mind of a Former BAC Short

Message.Msg: Hey, my friend, I am well aware of what the BAC short float is....The ratio is 1.2.....It is always that because there are alot of shares out there....But you know what, I cannot remember a time when BAC was not showing a 1.20 ration during my entire short through 2011...I can tell you this, though, when the Fed said BAC passed the stress test and when hedge funds found out that Buffett was buying into BAC a day before he actually did it, it felt as if the squeeze was on, if you know what I mean....I have been on the wrong side of some violent move ups during my short of BAC and I do not doubt the BAC will pressure shorts once again...
